data.title: Markdown: Code blocks lose colorization sometimes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a markdown file with the following contents:
   
   ```
   asdf
   
   `qwer` `zxcv`
   ```
2. Both `qwer` and `zxcv` should be colorized.
   
   ![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1096010/18449965/1ecd4780-78e6-11e6-8b90-acc63d9f11b9.png)
3. Delete the empty line (line 2).
4. `qwer` remains colorized. `zxcv` loses color.
   
   ![2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1096010/18450006/4d2e2e5a-78e6-11e6-8a8b-ce29173b3f7a.png)

data.title: Up/down after selecting text moves text cursor corresponding to end of selection, not its current position

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Type multiple lines of text:
   
   ```
   asdf
   qwer
   ```
2. Position text cursor at line 1 column 4, i.e. between `d` and `f`, then hold <kbd>Shift</kbd> and press <kbd>Left arrow</kbd> twice to select `s` and `a`. Now `asd` should be selected and text cursor should be at line 1 column 1.
3. Release <kbd>Shift</kbd> and press <kbd>Down arrow</kbd>

Expected:

Selection is cleared and text cursor is at line 2 column 1, i.e. before `q`.

Actual:

Selection is cleared and text cursor is at line 2 column 3, i.e. between `e` and `r`.

data.title: Provide command to focus most recently used editor group
data.body:
In order to create custom keybindings to toggle focus between the editor and something such as the terminal panel, a command to focus the active/most recently used editor group needs to be added. I believe this is the best that can be accomplished currently:

Focuses the first group, meaning if the second or third editor groups were focused this would feel wrong:

``` json
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
                            "when": "!terminalFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.focusFirstEditorGroup",
                            "when": "terminalFocus" }
```

Or this which focused the most recently used editor group but opens the last editor/file in the group:

``` json
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.terminal.focus",
                            "when": "!terminalFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+`",          "command": "workbench.action.openLastEditorInGroup",
                            "when": "terminalFocus" }
```

Some context on request: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11714#issuecomment-245859561

data.title: Debugger runtime shown against an extension seems confusing
data.body:
In the latest update there's a contributions tab that shows things that an extension contributes. For Dart Code it shows `node` as the debugger runtime:

![Debugger runtime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/18445096/d948e98e-7913-11e6-80f5-738c42991283.png)

I guess this is because our debug adapter is written in TS (and is therefore invoked via `node`). The adapter then launches Dart with debug flags and interacts with it.

Have we done something incorrectly or is this expected? If it's expected, is showing this runtime here useful to the extension user? It seems a bit confusing to me.

data.title: Deactivating extensions do not always have enough time to clean up
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Check out https://github.com/MSLaguana/vscode_deactivate_process_issue
2. Run the extension in that project
3. In the command palette, run "Spawn child process"
4. Navigate to `localhost:8080` and verify that a webserver is running
5. In the command palette, run "Kill child process"
6. Navigate to `localhost:8080` and verify that no webserver is running; the cleanup command works correctly.
7. In the command palette, run "Spawn child process", then close the experimental vscode instance
8. Navigate to `localhost:8080` and verify that the webserver is still running

We ran into this issue at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-react-native/issues/300 where during normal usage of the extension, we start a long-running child process which we want to clean up when the extension stops.

Specifically we are trying to run `child_process.spawn("react-native.cmd", ...)`, which ends up creating an instance of `cmd /c react-native.cmd` that in turn creates the desired `node cli.js ...`. We would like to make sure that descendant process is cleaned up, but because there is an extra layer of indirection we cannot simply call `child_proc.kill()` since that kills the `cmd` process but not the `node` process.

To work around this, on windows we use `taskkill /T` to kill the `cmd` process and all its descendants. This works fine during normal operation, but when the extension is terminating invoking `taskkill` is an async exec operation and so it does not complete. I also tried using `exec-sync` but that didn't help either.

Any suggestions on how to improve our behaviour here instead of leaking processes?

data.title: Integrated Terminal createNew command throws an error on Insiders
data.body:

1. Open the terminal (using Ctrl + ` or otherwise.)
2. Kill the terminal.

data.body:

const BACK_TICK_CHAR_CODE = '`'.charCodeAt(0);
const SINGLE_QUOTE_CHAR_CODE = '`'.charCodeAt(0);

I didn't want to touch those two lines in case something was forgotten there?

P.S. Please use `CharCode`, TypeScript will inline the values and will make it fast & readable.

data.title: Bad cursor position after snippet insertion
data.body:
With the following snippet:

``` json
{
    "after": {
        "prefix": "aftr",
        "body": [
            "afterEach((done) => {",
            "${1}\ttest",
            "});"
        ],
        "description": "Mocha BDD: after() | afterEach()"
    }
}
```

Cursor stays here:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/18441918/0f9a9c76-790f-11e6-8ed4-0bca3bdac9db.png)
## 

My settings are 

``` json
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "editor.fontSize": 14,
    "editor.lineHeight": 20,
    "css.lint.emptyRules": "warning",
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "editor.fontFamily": "Fira Code",
    "editor.fontLigatures": true,
    "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true,
    "editor.renderWhitespace": true,
    "editor.lineNumbers": true,
    "diffEditor.renderSideBySide": true,
    "files.autoSave": "afterDelay",
    "editor.folding": false,
    "svgviewer.transparencygrid": false,
    "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0,
    "workbench.editor.enablePreview": false,
    "git.autofetch": true,
    "workbench.editor.showTabs": false,
    "window.openFilesInNewWindow": true,
    "update.channel": "none"
}
```

data.title: Allow to show multiple panels at the same time (split pane)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan

![2016-09-12-ifk3n](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1612675/18441274/17f0863c-7915-11e6-8742-4635fab63e57.png)

While there's a double pane for files, an errors/terminal board can't be divided into two panes right now. This would be very helpful, since terminal and errors are usually needed together - you type some code and see compilation notes in terminal. Most of the time there's too much whitespace at the right side of the terminal/errors board, so we can add same double-pane toggle icon [ | ] at the right side of the board and make it work:
- if double-pane mode is switched on and one side is empty, then, we would add a terminal/errors board right there
- if double-pane mode is switched off, then, make visible only left board, right one should disappear
- if one of the boards is switched off using hotkey, then, remove it and make a board single-pane (if there's one board in double-pane - remove both panes)

data.title: possible regression in 1.5.1 with self-signed certificates?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1 (1.5.1)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Upgrade to 1.5.1 in an environment with self-signed certificates and a transparent SSL proxy
2. Observe error message `self signed certificate in certificate chain` on startup, and `Marketplace returned 'ECONNREFUSED'. Please check the 'http.proxy' setting` when trying to search for plugins.

No changes were made between 1.4 and 1.5.1, and everything worked as expected with the previous version. Setting `"http.proxyStrictSSL": false` did not resolve the issue.

data.title: Add File Explorer Setting to hide files .extensions ( not always necessary with icons )

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Now with a colorful explorer with icons, I wish to hide the .extensions in explorer while keeping them for empty file names like .gitignore.

![vscode-react](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11414503/18437519/aa148b66-78fd-11e6-955a-271ff4a69817.png)

Icons are great because they move the file type to the left of the file name but without this option I still feel some of the friction to find a file in the tree could be avoided.

Settings example :

```
// Controls if the explorer should hide file extensions.
"explorer.hideFileExtension": true,

// Controls if the explorer should show files extension for empty file names.
"explorer.showFileExtensionForEmptyFileNames": true,
```

For files using the same language but with different extensions :  icon variations.

![boxstarter-compare](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11414503/18438830/3ede77a2-7903-11e6-93a5-5844d9098cf7.png)

FileNameWithoutExtension() for human !

data.title: Bug in How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source documentation
data.body:
I've now successfully built vscode on Ubuntu 14.04 ARMhf. 
Note the documentation is wrong. 
It states one needs NPM < 3.9. 
This is wrong. I installed 3.8 (3.8.4), and it still failed. 
Then i installed 3.7 and it still failed. 
Then I installed 3.5 and it still failed. 
Then I installed 3.1, and the build ran, but not vscode 
==> error Cannot find module 'jsonc-parser'. 
==> +subsequent errors
One needs to manually 
npm install jsonc-parser  
then it ran (so far without bug) 

Also, electron downloaded a second time after i just installed jsonc-parser. 
I don't know if you just download it, or just when there are changes, but if it's that large and takes that long, it shouldn't download a second time. 

Also tell Scott hanselmann to fix his blog article on
http://www.hanselman.com/blog/BuildingVisualStudioCodeOnARaspberryPi3.aspx 
it should definitely reference a fixed version of 
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source
- VSCode Version:
  git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode
  as per 20160912, 11:40 CEST
- OS Version:
  uname -a
  Linux localhost 3.10.18 #1 SMP Tue Aug 2 21:26:16 PDT 2016 armv7l armv7l armv7l GNU/Linux

lsb_release -cds
Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS
trusty
# nodejs --version

v6.5.0

npm --version
3.1.3

Steps to Reproduce:
cd ~
mkdir sources
cd sources
sudo apt-get purge nodejs npm
curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_6.x | sudo -E bash -
apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y nodejs
nodejs --version ==> v6.5.0
npm --version  ==> 3.10.3
# Downgrade NPM to < 3.9 !WRONG!

npm install npm@3.1 -g
npm --version ==> 3.1.3

(trusty)root@localhost:~/sources# git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode
(trusty)root@localhost:~/sources# cd vscode/
# Fix bug: Cannot find module 'jsonc-parser'.

(trusty)root@localhost:~/sources# npm install jsonc-parser  
(trusty)root@localhost:~/sources/vscode# ./scripts/npm.sh install --arch=armhf
(trusty)root@localhost:~/sources/vscode# ./scripts/code.sh

data.title: Allow to configure settings per file type

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.1
- OS Version: OS-X 10.11.6

Currently, the configuration switches that control indentation (editor.tabSize, editor.insertSpaces) can be configured globally or per-workspace.  But it's not unusual to work on different types of files within the same workspace that need different indentation styles.  For example, Go source files always use tabSize=8, insertSpaces=false (it's a language standard), but the same workspaces very often contain other types of files (e.g. Markdown, HTML, JavaScript, etc.) where those are not the desired settings.  It is irritating to have to set the indentation style manually whenever creating a new file.  Instead, the indentation settings should be language-specific, rather like snippets.

data.title: .JS files no longer open as Javascript after latest update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.1 (07d663dc1bd848161edf4cd4ce30cce410d3d877, 2016-09-08T21:33:49.307Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a .js file
2. In the bottom-right corner it appears as "Plain Text"
3. If I click on the "Plain Text" link and choose "Configure File Association for '.js'" a settings.json tab appears. I can click save, but it doesn't appear to have any effect.

So now I need to manually choose "JavaScript" for each .js file I open.
The project I work with also have JavaScript React files (.jsx) and they correctly open as React.

This used to work with the previous version and only started appearing as I upgraded to 1.5.1.
